Dean's List
For Frosh

A dean's list for the freshman
class has been established for
the first time. In the past only
a letter of recognition was sent
freshmen, congratulating
to
them on their academic accomplishment.
Selected on the basis of their
grades, those eligible for the
dean's list were to have no more
than 2 B's and the rest A's. An
exception was made for one student carrying an extra heavy
load.
The School of Engineering also
established a freshman dean's
list last fall. Students in engineering were honored for their
academic excellence in the 1964
spring term.
The Hopkins students are of
such caliber that the Faculty
of Philosophy felt a dean's list
for upperclassmen would not
further motivate students. Outstanding students are, however,
recognized by election to Phi
Beta Kappa, and graduation
with departmental or general
honors.
The following students were
selected for the Freshman Dean's
list as a consequence of the excellence of their scholarship.
Each of these students will receive a letter of congratulations:

and wordy."

Honor
In Honor Commission trials
conducted during February,
two students, sophomores in
the Arts & Sciences, were
found guilty of honor violations. The course concerned
in each case was in English:
the penalty imposed in each
case was the constitutional
penalty or its equivalent.
In four other trials, four
students were found not guilty
of
honor
violations; the
courses concerned were in
Psychology, Spanish, Art
Biology.

A new Reserve Officer Training Corps program permits selected
college sophomores to be commissioned as Army Second Lieutenants in two years. You can do this by:
1. Completing a special 6-week summer camp between your sophomore and junior years.

2. Completing the 2-year Advanced Course at any school offering
the ROTC program.

What are the benefits of Army ROTC training?
•

Management training for success in civilian or military life.

• $40 per month pay while attending the Advanced Course, plus
uniforms; pay and paid travel for summer camps.

Ivy League In The Committee Room

By HENRY KORN

Composition Editor
Ron Coonin

While the creation of The Lang Range Planning Committee is a constructive step in determining the future direction of our University
we must make certain that the emphasis placed
on the committee does not overshadow the critical
issues we face at present. While hailing the study
of a future fusion of Philosophy and Engineering,
the implementation of a full graduate program in
the liberal arts we must also recognize the need
to deal with pressing if less lofty) problems.
They must be dealt with if the University is to
move forward.

Editors of a college newspaper are unique only in
must take time from their studies to remain
they
that
cognizant of all that is happening within their community.
After fulfilling our duties and watching over the
Homewood Scene for a year, we see increasing signs
that some Hopkins people are not content to allow the
University to drift but are demanding thoughtful criticism as a starter, and action as a goal. This refreshing
discontent comes mainly from the faculty, from the
men that are serving on the Long Range Planning Committee. It is good to see some dynamism in the faculty;
it would be even better if in the past year we had seen
some of this dynamism in graduate and undergraduate
students as well. To he sure students are discontented,
manifests itself in the
but their discontent generally
"dorm food stinks. ..
e.g.,
mutterings;
form of timless
I haven't seen my advisor in three years. .. they don't
give a damn about undegraduates around here... they
treat graduate students like scum". .. etc.
Some graduate students simply do not care enough
to think through the problems they face at Hopkins.
Others are genuinely concerned but fear—with apparent
justification—to openly express their dissatisfaction. The
latter are likely to seek recourse through the NewsLetter."Why don't you do something about this?",
they ask.
Undergraduates are in even more of a fix. They
enjoy being discontented. Upperclassmen tell incoming
freshmen just how had some things at Hopkins are,
and the freshmen soon find that their experience confirms what they have been told. Having discovered the
basic truths of the Homewood, students accept them,
complain about them to each other, write home about
them, and tell their girls about them. But that's all.
They are simply too dull or too lazy to think out logical
arguments for changing the existing order. One undergraduate group that tries to discuss problems is the
Student Council. It would, indeed, be cruel to say that
the Student Council has been something of a joke this
year; but such a description would at least he objective.
The Council's discussions are by and large petty if not
meaningless. When the Council does stumble on to
something significant it still takes the wrong action.
We find that with the undergraduates, as with graduate
students, the News-Letter is left to be the sole vehicle
of careful discussion and exposition of issues and problems at Homewood.
The major issues of the past two years—graduate
intructors, the Young Republicans, fraternity discrimination, the questionable adequacy of the dormitory facilities, and the issues of the Long-Range Planning Committee—have been raised and discussed in the NewsLetter; only later carried over into some other group,
if at all. This is not as it should be. The News-Letter
should serve as a forum where some issues can be
raised and discussed. But it is impossible for all the
issues that should he raised to be raised by one group.
The primary task of the News-Letter is to report
news.
No other task can be allowed to detract from
die
this function.
If neither the graduate nor undegraduate students

that face them, what are they to do? Keep trying to
form workable discussion groups? Forget about the
whole problem? Turn the problem over to the LRPC?
Or perhaps try a different idea that has worked at other
Schools. Some schools have set up group comprised of
students, faculty, and selected members of the Board of
Trustees and administrative personnel, to discuss their
mutual problems, each other's problems and the problems of their school as a whole.
The establishment of such a group might be coneidered at Hopkins. There are many obstacles, of course,
but the idea should not he summarily dismissed. Some
feel that such a group is not needed, because all administration personnel and members of the Board already
know some students. These contacts, however, do not
seem to have solved many problems. One should remember that it is not too difficult for a sharp member
of the administration to "snow" a sharp but inexperienced undergraduate or graduate student. Meeting as
a group, students, faculty, administration, and board
members would find it easier to pin each other down,
and their very numbers would mean that more shades
of opinion and more suggestions and ideas could be
entertained.
We suspect that the administration will be reluctant
to set up such a committee. Those who enjoy power
rarely are willing to give up even part of that power
or seek the help of those over whom they exercise that
power. Students and faculty will probably he forced to
combine forces in pressuring the administration to
establish the committee.

Professor Gildersleeve Heads
New Johns Hopkins University
By JAMES R. MEGINNISS
The chair of Greek, the first
professorship to be filled at the
new university, was offered by
President Gilman to the remarkable Basil L. Gildersieeve. In
the 40 years that followed, Prof.
Gildersleeve was to be an immeasurable benefit to the growth
and reputation of Hopkins.
Gilman had no doubts, such
as he was later to have about
the appointment of J. J. Sylvester, when it came to choosing
Gildersleeve. French, in his A
History of the University
Founded by Johns Hopkins,
writes: "The Gildersleeve Latin
Grammer, first published in 1867,
had been followed by other textbooks of such excellence that
their author was already widely
recognized. His literary taste and
skill; his nimble, if sometimes
caustic, wit; his sound judgement and breadth of outlook
made him an admirable senior
professor; and Gilman found in
him a trusted friend and advisor."
So much for the appointment,
but what about the man and
his background?
He had received his A.B. at
Princeton in 1849, when only 18,
and then went to Germany to
study at the Universities of
Berlin, Bann, and Gottingen. He
received his Ph.D. at the lastmentioned in 1853. At this point,
with his formal education under
his belt and his life (71 more
years) still ahead, he could
easily have become a poet Or
essayist, but instead he chose
the life of the scholar.
SCHOLARLY LIFE CHOSEN
1856 found him as Professor
of Greek at the University of
Virginia, in those turbulent times
just prior to the Civil War. When
war finally came, he enlisted in
the Confederate Cavalry, devoting his summers to fighting
and his winters to teaching
Greek. It was during one of these
summers that he received a
permanently laming wound while
fighting in the upper Shenandoah valley. Years later he was
to write, in the true spirit of his
chosen profession. A Southerner
in the Peloppenesian War with
many illuminating comparisons
between the two wars.
But Basil Gildersleeve's greatest accomplishments waited until l
he had begun his long and i
profitable association with the
Johns Hopkins University.
In May of 1877, Professor
Gildersleeve i now at Hopkins)
called a meeting at which the
American Philological Associa

tion was organized. The first
formal paper, presented to the
Association by one Charles L.
Lanman, was appropriately entitled: "The Two Original KAsounds
in
Indo-European."
Gildersleeve became president of
the Association, and continued to
hold that position until his retirement in 1915.
PHILOLOGICAL STUDIES
Not content to rest on past
accomplishments,
Gildersleeve
soon began to press for a Philological Journal, to support classical studies in this country. The
first edition of the American
Journal of Philology, under his
editorship, appeased in 1880. In
the first issue of his Journal,
Gildersleeve wrote: "With the
help of the most active and enterprising scholars of America,
with a large storehouse of European periodical literature for the
quickening and enriching of our
own work, with a generous support accorded in advance by the
munificence of our new university and by the fraternal spirit
of fellow -workers through the
length of the land, the Journal
enters upon a career that is full
of hope." His hope was fulfilled,
for the Journal earned a highly
recognized position, under his
forty years of editorship, and
still holds this reputation today.
Basil Gildersleeve was certainly not afraid of work. In a letter
dated August 15, 1879, he wrote
Gilman from his vacation spot
in Virginia: "... these last weeks
of vacation must be devoted as
far as possible to preparation for
next session, which promises to
be for me a year of very arduous

work. A trunk of books supplies
me with ample material for all
manner of lucubrations and I
hope to make my fortnight here
tell."
As a rough measure of the
tremendous literary and lingual
capacity of Giklensleeve, the
bibliographical list of his publications fills a full 32 pages in
Miller's Selections from the
Brief Mention of B. L. Gildersleeve.
This list of publications marks
a period of prolific productivity
extending from about 1843 to
1922 and includes such items as:
a Latin Grammer; numerous
Latin readers, exercise books,
and primers; editorials in newspapers; original poetry; edited
versions of Classical literature;
lengthy analyses of classical
works; book reviews; studies in
Greek syntax; essays on many
topics, including this travels'
biography; and criticism.
WRITES SOUTHERNER

Southerner in the Pelopponesian
War serves to convey some idea
of the man: "In 1860 I spent a
few days in Holland and among
my various excursions in that
fascinating country, I took a
solitary trip on a treckschuit
from Amsterdam to Delft. Holland was so true to Dutch pictures that there was a retrospective delight in the houses and
In the people. There was a charm
in the very signs, in the names
of the villas; for my knowledge
of Dutch had not passed beyond
the stage at which the Netherlandish tongue seems to be an

By HENRY KORN

Composition Editor
Ron Coonin

While the creation of The Lang Range Planning Committee is a constructive step in determining the future direction of our University
we must make certain that the emphasis placed
on the committee does not overshadow the critical
issues we face at present. While hailing the study
of a future fusion of Philosophy and Engineering,
the implementation of a full graduate program in
the liberal arts we must also recognize the need
to deal with pressing if less lofty) problems.
They must be dealt with if the University is to
move forward.

Editors of a college newspaper are unique only in
must take time from their studies to remain
they
that
cognizant of all that is happening within their community.
After fulfilling our duties and watching over the
Homewood Scene for a year, we see increasing signs
that some Hopkins people are not content to allow the
University to drift but are demanding thoughtful criticism as a starter, and action as a goal. This refreshing
discontent comes mainly from the faculty, from the
men that are serving on the Long Range Planning Committee. It is good to see some dynamism in the faculty;
it would be even better if in the past year we had seen
some of this dynamism in graduate and undergraduate
students as well. To he sure students are discontented,
manifests itself in the
but their discontent generally
"dorm food stinks. ..
e.g.,
mutterings;
form of timless
I haven't seen my advisor in three years. .. they don't
give a damn about undegraduates around here... they
treat graduate students like scum". .. etc.
Some graduate students simply do not care enough
to think through the problems they face at Hopkins.
Others are genuinely concerned but fear—with apparent
justification—to openly express their dissatisfaction. The
latter are likely to seek recourse through the NewsLetter."Why don't you do something about this?",
they ask.
Undergraduates are in even more of a fix. They
enjoy being discontented. Upperclassmen tell incoming
freshmen just how had some things at Hopkins are,
and the freshmen soon find that their experience confirms what they have been told. Having discovered the
basic truths of the Homewood, students accept them,
complain about them to each other, write home about
them, and tell their girls about them. But that's all.
They are simply too dull or too lazy to think out logical
arguments for changing the existing order. One undergraduate group that tries to discuss problems is the
Student Council. It would, indeed, be cruel to say that
the Student Council has been something of a joke this
year; but such a description would at least he objective.
The Council's discussions are by and large petty if not
meaningless. When the Council does stumble on to
something significant it still takes the wrong action.
We find that with the undergraduates, as with graduate
students, the News-Letter is left to be the sole vehicle
of careful discussion and exposition of issues and problems at Homewood.
The major issues of the past two years—graduate
intructors, the Young Republicans, fraternity discrimination, the questionable adequacy of the dormitory facilities, and the issues of the Long-Range Planning Committee—have been raised and discussed in the NewsLetter; only later carried over into some other group,
if at all. This is not as it should be. The News-Letter
should serve as a forum where some issues can be
raised and discussed. But it is impossible for all the
issues that should he raised to be raised by one group.
The primary task of the News-Letter is to report
news.
No other task can be allowed to detract from
die
this function.
If neither the graduate nor undegraduate students
can now meaningfully and productively discuss the issues
that face them, what are they to do? Keep trying to
form workable discussion groups? Forget about the
whole problem? Turn the problem over to the LRPC?
Or perhaps try a different idea that has worked at other
Schools. Some schools have set up group comprised of
students, faculty, and selected members of the Board of
Trustees and administrative personnel, to discuss their
mutual problems, each other's problems and the problems of their school as a whole.
The establishment of such a group might be coneidered at Hopkins. There are many obstacles, of course,
but the idea should not he summarily dismissed. Some
feel that such a group is not needed, because all administration personnel and members of the Board already
know some students. These contacts, however, do not
seem to have solved many problems. One should remember that it is not too difficult for a sharp member
of the administration to "snow" a sharp but inexperienced undergraduate or graduate student. Meeting as
a group, students, faculty, administration, and board
members would find it easier to pin each other down,
and their very numbers would mean that more shades
of opinion and more suggestions and ideas could be
entertained.
We suspect that the administration will be reluctant
to set up such a committee. Those who enjoy power
rarely are willing to give up even part of that power
or seek the help of those over whom they exercise that
power. Students and faculty will probably he forced to
combine forces in pressuring the administration to
establish the committee.

Who can explain the miniature free-standing

Have we not lost sight of perspective when
our planning committee proposes to consider
the matriculation of undergraduate women while

Professor Gildersleeve Heads
New Johns Hopkins University
By JAMES R. MEGINNISS
The chair of Greek, the first
professorship to be filled at the
new university, was offered by
President Gilman to the remarkable Basil L. Gildersieeve. In
the 40 years that followed, Prof.
Gildersleeve was to be an immeasurable benefit to the growth
and reputation of Hopkins.
Gilman had no doubts, such
as he was later to have about
the appointment of J. J. Sylvester, when it came to choosing
Gildersleeve. French, in his A
History of the University
Founded by Johns Hopkins,
writes: "The Gildersleeve Latin
Grammer, first published in 1867,
had been followed by other textbooks of such excellence that
their author was already widely
recognized. His literary taste and
skill; his nimble, if sometimes
caustic, wit; his sound judgement and breadth of outlook
made him an admirable senior
professor; and Gilman found in
him a trusted friend and advisor."
So much for the appointment,
but what about the man and
his background?
He had received his A.B. at
Princeton in 1849, when only 18,
and then went to Germany to
study at the Universities of
Berlin, Bann, and Gottingen. He
received his Ph.D. at the lastmentioned in 1853. At this point,
with his formal education under
his belt and his life (71 more
years) still ahead, he could
easily have become a poet Or
essayist, but instead he chose
the life of the scholar.
SCHOLARLY LIFE CHOSEN
1856 found him as Professor
of Greek at the University of
Virginia, in those turbulent times
just prior to the Civil War. When
war finally came, he enlisted in
the Confederate Cavalry, devoting his summers to fighting
and his winters to teaching
Greek. It was during one of these
summers that he received a
permanently laming wound while
fighting in the upper Shenandoah valley. Years later he was
to write, in the true spirit of his
chosen profession. A Southerner
in the Peloppenesian War with
many illuminating comparisons
between the two wars.
But Basil Gildersleeve's greatest accomplishments waited until l
he had begun his long and i
profitable association with the
Johns Hopkins University.
In May of 1877, Professor
Gildersleeve i now at Hopkins)
called a meeting at which the
American Philological Associa

tion was organized. The first
formal paper, presented to the
Association by one Charles L.
Lanman, was appropriately entitled: "The Two Original KAsounds
in
Indo-European."
Gildersleeve became president of
the Association, and continued to
hold that position until his retirement in 1915.
PHILOLOGICAL STUDIES
Not content to rest on past
accomplishments,
Gildersleeve
soon began to press for a Philological Journal, to support classical studies in this country. The
first edition of the American
Journal of Philology, under his
editorship, appeased in 1880. In
the first issue of his Journal,
Gildersleeve wrote: "With the
help of the most active and enterprising scholars of America,
with a large storehouse of European periodical literature for the
quickening and enriching of our
own work, with a generous support accorded in advance by the
munificence of our new university and by the fraternal spirit
of fellow -workers through the
length of the land, the Journal
enters upon a career that is full
of hope." His hope was fulfilled,
for the Journal earned a highly
recognized position, under his
forty years of editorship, and
still holds this reputation today.
Basil Gildersleeve was certainly not afraid of work. In a letter
dated August 15, 1879, he wrote
Gilman from his vacation spot
in Virginia: "... these last weeks
of vacation must be devoted as
far as possible to preparation for
next session, which promises to
be for me a year of very arduous

work. A trunk of books supplies
me with ample material for all
manner of lucubrations and I
hope to make my fortnight here
tell."
As a rough measure of the
tremendous literary and lingual
capacity of Giklensleeve, the
bibliographical list of his publications fills a full 32 pages in
Miller's Selections from the
Brief Mention of B. L. Gildersleeve.
This list of publications marks
a period of prolific productivity
extending from about 1843 to
1922 and includes such items as:
a Latin Grammer; numerous
Latin readers, exercise books,
and primers; editorials in newspapers; original poetry; edited
versions of Classical literature;
lengthy analyses of classical
works; book reviews; studies in
Greek syntax; essays on many
topics, including this travels'
biography; and criticism.
WRITES SOUTHERNER
One brief passage from A
Southerner in the Pelopponesian
War serves to convey some idea
of the man: "In 1860 I spent a
few days in Holland and among
my various excursions in that
fascinating country, I took a
solitary trip on a treckschuit
from Amsterdam to Delft. Holland was so true to Dutch pictures that there was a retrospective delight in the houses and
In the people. There was a charm
in the very signs, in the names
of the villas; for my knowledge
of Dutch had not passed beyond
the stage at which the Netherlandish tongue seems to be an

Seminar Set
Dr. Walter Ullmann, Visiting
professor of Humanistic Studies
at the Johns Hcpkins University,
will deliver three lectures on
-The Individual and Society in
the Middle Ages" March 8, 9 and
10 at 4 P.M. in the Garrett Roam
of the Homewood Library. All
lectures are open to the public.
The lectures are part of the
University's Humanities Seminars, a five year program begun
in 1963 and designed to promote
interdepartmental study in the
humanities. Each year a particular topic or period is the
subject of investigation and discussion.
Professor Ullmann is Reader in
Medieval Ecclesiastical History
at the University of Cambridge
and a Fellow of Trinity College,
Cambridge. He has also taught
at the Universities of Vienna and
Leeds.
Professor Ulim a:nn's extensive
writings in medieval and papal
history include books on "The
Medieval . Idea of, Law," "The
Origins of the Great Schism,"
"Principles of Government and
Politics in the Middle Ages."
His lectures in the humanities
seminars will deal with "The Abstract Thesis: The Ecclesiological
and Corporational Theme of the
Subject in Society" (March 8);
"The Practical Thesis: The
Constitutional Significance of the
Feudal Relationship and its
Bearing upon the Individual"
(March 91; and "The Humanistic Thesis: The Release of the
Subject and His Emergence as a
Citizen" (March 10).
